{{Infobox NRHP | name = Civil War Memorial | nrhp_type = cp | nocat = yes | partof = Sycamore Historic District | partof_refnum = 78003104<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> | image = Sycamore Il Civil War Memorial6.jpg | caption = | location = [[Sycamore, Illinois|Sycamore]], [[DeKalb County, Illinois]], [[United States|USA]] | nearest_city = | lat_degrees = 41 | lat_minutes = 59 | lat_seconds = 2 | lat_direction = N | long_degrees = 88 | long_minutes = 41 | long_seconds = 39 | long_direction = W | built = 1896 | architect = | architecture = | added = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | mpsub = | governing_body = [[DeKalb County, Illinois|DeKalb County]] }} The '''Civil War Memorial''', in the [[DeKalb County, Illinois|DeKalb County]] county seat of [[Sycamore, Illinois|Sycamore]], [[Illinois]], United States, is located in front of the DeKalb County Courthouse on a public square. The memorial was erected in 1896 and dedicated in 1897. The structure is a memorial to the thousands of DeKalb County residents who served in the American Civil War. It incorporates an [[obelisk]] which rises to 50 feet (15.2 m) in height. The base is adorned with copper sculpture, completed by an unknown sculptor. On the east facade of the memorial the word "Antietam", denoting the [[Battle of Antietam]], is misspelled. This work of [[public art]] underwent its first restoration work in 2005-2006.
The memorial is included among the 187 buildings and structures considered [[Contributing property|contributing properties]] to the [[Sycamore Historic District]]. The [[historic district]] was added to the U.S. [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1978. The structure also has artistic significance as it is listed by the Smithsonian American Art Museum in their research database. It is one of the few [[sculpture]]s in DeKalb County found within that database. The Civil War Memorial is owned by DeKalb County.
==History== The DeKalb County Civil War Memorial and the sculpture that adorns it was created by an unknown sculptor and installed in front of the DeKalb County Courthouse in 1896.<ref name=prop>"[http://gis.hpa.state.il.us/hargis/ Civil War Memorial]," Property Information Report, Sycamore Historic District, HAARGIS Database, ''Illinois Historic Preservation Agency''. Retrieved July 8, 2007.</ref><ref name=smith>"[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=1P838908K16J6.88&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!313453~!29&ri=6&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=DeKalb,+Illinois&index=.GW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=6 Civil War Memorial], Art Inventories Catalog (IAS IL000424), Smithsonian Institution Research Information System, ''Smithsonian American Art Museum''. Retrieved July 8, 2007.</ref> The county-owned memorial stands on the public square in Sycamore, the county seat and is 50 feet (15.2 m) tall.<ref name=smith/> The structure was dedicated on June 24, 1897 as a memorial to the 2,388 people from DeKalb County who served in the military during the [[American Civil War]].<ref name=smith/><ref name=image>Ritzman, Floyd. [http://lincoln.lib.niu.edu/fimage/dekalb/image.php?d_id=607 Image of dedication ceremony], (1897), Abraham Lincoln Historical Digitization Project, Northern Illinois University Libraries. Retrieved February 28, 2007.</ref><ref name=hernandez>Hernandez, Aracely. [http://www.daily-chronicle.com/articles/2005/07/23/news/news04.txt Civil War monuments are getting a facelift], ''Daily Chronicle'', July 23, 2005. Retrieved February 28, 2007.</ref> [[File:Sycamore Il Civil War Memorial2.jpg|thumb|right|The soldier figure atop the monument's [[obelisk]].]] In July 2005 the statues adorning the monument underwent a [[Art conservation and restoration|restoration]].<ref name=hernandez/> DeKalb County appropriated [[United States dollar|US$]]15,000 for the project which, among other tasks, repaired a split seam in one of the soldier statues and a crack in the other sculpture's base.<ref name=hernandez/> The project took approximately six months; the statues were removed for the duration of the restoration work and reinstalled in March 2006. During the restoration it was revealed that the statues, thought to be [[bronze]], were actually [[copper]].<ref name=herra>Herra, Dana. [http://www.daily-chronicle.com/articles/2006/03/02/news/news02.txt Civil War statues reinstalled after overdue cleaning], ''Daily Chronicle'', March 2, 2006. Retrieved February 28, 2007.</ref> The work, the first in the 110-year history of the memorial, was completed at a cost of $16,500.<ref name=herra/> Three months after the work was completed one of the statues was removed for a second time because the metal began to [[Oxidation|oxidize]].<ref name=herra2>Herra, Dana. [http://www.daily-chronicle.com/articles/2006/06/08/news/news04.txt Green soldier gets second scrubbing], ''Daily Chronicle'', June 8, 2006. Retrieved February 28, 2007.</ref>
==Design== [[File:Sycamore Il Civil War Memorial7.jpg|thumb|right|"Antietam" is misspelled on the east side of the memorial.]] The 50-foot (15.2-m) tall memorial has base dimensions of 10 feet (3 m) by 6 feet (1.8 m).<ref name=smith/> The monument is constructed from a combination of marble, masonry, and the metal used for the sculpted copper and masonry soldiers. The structure also incorporated wood into its design.<ref name=smith/> The [[rifle]]s the figures on the base hold and the bases that they stand on are made of wood.<ref name=smith/> The front facade is adorned with a marble plate engraved with an excerpt from U.S. President [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s [[Gettysburg Address]].<ref name=smith/> Each of the other facades, also marble faced, are emblazoned with the names of major battles and campaigns of the war. The word "Antietam," representing the [[Battle of Antietam]], is misspelled on the east, [[marble]] facade of the memorial as "Anteitam."<ref name=chron>[http://www.daily-chronicle.com/articles/2006/07/26/neighbors/neighbors03.txt Road Rally drove into Sycamore's past], '[[Daily Chronicle]]', July 26, 2006. Retrieved February 17, 2007.</ref>
The two [[copper]] statues, each standing 6 feet (1.8 m) tall, flank the [[obelisk]] which rises to a masonry soldier statue, instead of the typical [[Apex (geometry)|apex]] of an obelisk. The figure atop the [[granite]] obelisk is a mustached American Civil War soldier dressed in a long coat, a cape, and a cap. In the figure's right hand he holds the handle of his sword and the sword's tip rests in front of his right foot. In the soldier's left hand is a flag. Below the apex of the obelisk, on the memorial's base, are two additional sculpted figures, a [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] infantry soldier and a [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] cavalry soldier. The Union infantryman is dressed in a cap, long coat, and a cape, much like the figure atop the obelisk. The Union cavalryman, standing on the east side of the base, is dressed in a brimmed hat and short jacket.<ref name=smith/>
==Significance== The 1974 Illinois Historic Sites Survey Inventory found the DeKalb County Civil War Memorial significant in the areas of [[military]] and [[sculpture]]. At the time of the 1974 survey, the memorial was considered in "excellent" and "not altered" condition.<ref name=ihs>"[http://gis.hpa.state.il.us/PDFs/143705.pdf Civil War Memorial]", ([[PDF]]), Illinois Historic Sites Survey Inventory Form, 1974, HAARGIS Database, ''Illinois Historic Preservation Agency''. Retrieved July 8, 2007.</ref> It is also one of the few sculptures in [[DeKalb County, Illinois|DeKalb County]] that is listed in the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]]'s Smithsonian Institution Research Information System (SIRIS).<ref name=siris>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ Smithsonian Institution Research Information System], Art Inventories Catalog, ''Smithsonian American Art Museum''. Retrieved July 8, 2007.</ref> The Civil War Memorial is listed as a [[contributing property]] to the [[Sycamore Historic District]].<ref name=distlist>"[http://gis.hpa.state.il.us/hargis/ Sycamore Historic District]," National Register District Report, HAARGIS Database, ''Illinois Historic Preservation Agency.'' Retrieved July 8, 2007.</ref> The [[historic district]] joined the U.S. [[National Register of Historic Places]] on May 2, 1978.<ref name=nris/> As a part of the Sycamore Historic District, the National Register classifies the DeKalb County Civil War Memorial as an "[[Property type (National Register of Historic Places)#Object|object]]."<ref name=prop/>
